references:
Although there is a lot of research devoted to studying energy-efficient FEEL [28, 29, 30, 8, 31], our work differs from these works as shown in Table I.
Specifically, we adopt a unique approach that allows for the fine-grained selection of training data for improved energy efficiency of FEEL. Our proposed approach is motivated by the fact that not all local data samples can significantly contribute to the global modelÂ [32]. Throughout this work, we jointly consider the learning algorithm and the corresponding imbalanced local data samples as well as resource and system constraints.

The considered FEEL system consists of a set of end devices ğŠğŠ\mathbf{K} that are connected to the edge server as shown inÂ Fig.Â 1.
The edge server is located in the contiguity of ğŠğŠ\mathbf{K} workers to organize and coordinate the training process.
Each worker kâˆˆğŠğ‘˜ğŠk\in\mathbf{K} uses its own data ğ’Ÿksubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜\mathcal{D}_{k} to train its model Î¸ksubscriptğœƒğ‘˜\mathcal{\theta}_{k} locally and then sends the updates (i.e., weights and biases) back to the server, where ğ’Ÿk={xk,dâˆˆâ„d,yk,dâˆˆâ„}subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ‘‘superscriptâ„ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜ğ‘‘â„\mathcal{D}_{k}=\{{x}_{k,d}\in\mathbb{R}^{d},y_{k,d}\in\mathbb{R}\}, and |ğ’Ÿk|subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜|\mathcal{D}_{k}| is the portion of data samples and the whole data among workers is
Dâ‰œâˆ‘k=1K|ğ’Ÿk|â‰œğ·superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜D\triangleq\sum_{k=1}^{K}|\mathcal{D}_{k}| where K=|ğŠ|ğ¾ğŠK=|\mathbf{K}|.
Here, xk,dsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ‘‘{x}_{k,d} is the dğ‘‘d-dimensional input data vector at the kğ‘˜k-th worker, and yk,dsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜ğ‘‘y_{k,d} is the corresponding label associated with xk,dsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ‘‘{x}_{k,d}.
In return, the server collects and fuses all the workersâ€™ updates to build a global model.
In each FEEL round, the server sets a deadline constraint to synchronize the updates and avoid long waiting times.
Initially, the server sends random parameters Î¸0subscriptğœƒ0\mathcal{\theta}_{0} to all selected workers to start the training. On the worker side, the received global model is used as a reference to train the local models and control the divergence.
All these steps incur massive energy consumption; thus, for each worker to join the learning process, local data samples, energy budget, FEEL round deadline, and computation and communication capabilities are considered to ensure a robust FEEL system and avoid losing selected worker updates due to insufficient energy or FEEL round deadline time out.
To facilitate the presentation, we summarize the utilized main symbols in Table II.

For comparison, we use the baseline FEEL Algorithm and the optimization method as in

where all data samples are included for local training, and the updates are not synchronized.
We use the MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets under a realistic federated setting with i.i.d and non-i.i.d data distributions. We use feed-forward neural network model for MNIST and convolutional neural networks (CNN) model for CIFAR-10. 
For the i.i.d, the dataset is randomly partitioned into

pieces that correspond to the workers, and each worker is assigned one part.
For the non-i.i.d, the data is first partitioned into

parts that correspond to the classification classes.
Each part is further partitioned into different shards; then, each worker is assigned only

classes.
For each worker, the local data is split into

for testing.
We utilize the mini-batch SGD as a local solver with a batch size
and evaluate the global model every FEEL round. For all experiments, the results are collected and averaged over five trials.
